metadata.title: Diffuse Idiopathic Skeletal Hyperostosis (DISH)
synonyms: (22) generalized juxta-articular  ossifications of ligaments of the vertebral column
anatomical location body part affected: Most common location is the lower thoracic spine (T7–T11).(1) Can also affect cervical spine C3–C7,  levels of the lumbar spine, and extremities of the shoulder, elbow, hip, knee, and heel
description: Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH) is an idiopathic disease characterized by osteophyte formation in the spine. There are 3 hallmark signs of the disease:(2,3) –Heterotopicosteophytes involving at least 4 contiguous vertebral levels –Preservation of the disk spaces –Absence of any apophyseal joint degeneration or sacroiliac inflammatory changes
Elbow DISH is classified as having both elbow and thoracospinal hyperostosis(20)

M48.1.Optional: supplementary subclassification to indicate site of involvement

(ICD.base: codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)
(ICD.Reimbursement:: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been
identified. Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage
(ICD.Presentation/signs: Presentation/signs and symptoms:  DISH is generally asymptomatic,(4) but patients
(ICD.Decreased: Decreased ROM in spinal mobility (flexion, extension, side bending, rotation)(4,6)
(ICD.Chronic: Chronic neck and low back pain(3,5,7)
(ICD.20%: 20% to 30% of persons with DISH present with dysphagia

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified. Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage -Presentation/signs and symptoms:  DISH is generally asymptomatic,(4) but patients might present with the following: -Spinal stiffness(5) -Decreased ROM in spinal mobility (flexion, extension, side bending, rotation)(4,6)  -Radicular symptoms(7,8) -Chronic neck and low back pain(3,5,7) -Dysphagia(1,5,8,9,22) -20% to 30% of persons with DISH present with dysphagia -Dysphonia(9) -Unstable thoracolumbar fractures(8) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
presentation signs and symptoms: DISH is generally asymptomatic,(4) but patients might present with the following: -Spinal stiffness(5) -Decreased ROM in spinal mobility (flexion, extension, side bending, rotation)(4,6)  -Radicular symptoms(7,8) -Chronic neck and low back pain(3,5,7) -Dysphagia(1,5,8,9,22) -20% to 30% of persons with DISH present with dysphagia -Dysphonia(9) -Unstable thoracolumbar fractures(8) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors

causes: No known specific causes of DISH have been identified(1)
pathogenesis: Osteophytes present along the anterolateral margins of 4 contiguous vertebral bodies and calcification of entheseal sites(1)–Ossifications start at the insertion point of ligaments, tendons, and joint capsules (entheses)
Osteophyte formation affecting the anterior longitudinal ligament(5)

overall contraindications precautions: Patients with DISH are at increased risk for fractures
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan

contraindications precautions to examina: Patients with DISH often are misdiagnosed as having ankylosing spondylitis. It is important for the examiner to understand the differences between the two conditions(23) –The diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis depends on the presence of inflammatory back pain or restriction of spinal mobility when radiographic sacroiliitis is present(3)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: When did the symptoms begin? How old is the patient? Has the patient noticed any changes in swallowing? Has the patient noticed any changes in ability to speak? Any changes in spinal mobility? Has the patient had any radiographic images of the spine taken?

course of treatment.medical management: Depending on severity and location of DISH, surgical removal of osteophytes may be required.(7,12) Treatment is aimed at decreasing pain and maintaining physical function(7)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken? NSAIDs are commonly prescribed for pain relief.(12)Longterm  use of retinoids (e.g., isotretinoin [Amnesteem, Claravis]) can increase risk for DISH
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:
Radiographic imaging is the diagnostic gold standard for DISH(1,13)
Imaging will show new osteophyte formation at the anterior aspect of at least 4 contiguous vertebral bodies when viewed from the lateral aspect
Imaging will show ossification of the anterior longitudinal ligament and extraspinal ligaments(11)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased)(9) -ambulation -weight-bearing -spinal movement -sit to stand(9) -standing erect posture -minimized movement
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms. Pain may distribute along the lateral margins of the thoracic and lumbar spine.(5) It may also involve the peripheral joints of the shoulders, elbows, and entheseal regions.(#) DISH more commonly affects the right side of the spine than the left(4)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., pain vs. stiffness, constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables. Stiffness is more evident in the morning and late evening(5)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night. Are they due to symptoms of pain and stiffness?
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., dizziness, bowel/bladder/sexual dysfunction, saddle anesthesia). Note any changes in swallowing or phonation; note any breathing difficulty
history of present illness.respiratory status: Patients with severe cases of DISH involving the cervical segments may require a tracheostomy and be intubated to open up the airways(14) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Previous history of spinal injury or dysfunction?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, metabolic disorders, endocrine disorders, parathyroid disorders, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs). Patient may be taking NSAIDs, analgesics, or myorelaxants(12)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in recreational or competitive sports? Are there any desired activities that the patient cannot participate in currently due to symptoms?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Patient may present with decreased functional range of the spine and shoulder, limiting ability to dress, shower, and ambulate. Determine any use of assistive devices such as a single-point  cane, walker, and/or wheelchair
social and occupational history.living environment: stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Assess BMI of patient. Those with higher BMI are at increased risk for DISH(6,7,11)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Determine if an assistive device is used by the patient. Ensure proper use of assistive device as well as proper height setting
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess static and dynamic balance. Utilize functional balance assessments such as the Berg Balance Scale and the Timed Up and Go (TUG) test to determine balance. Patients with DISH are at increased risk for fractures(8,13)
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Perform a gait assessment to determine any abnormalities in gait patternExamine the end feels and joint integrity of proximal joints and spinal segments. Determine hypermobility versus hypomobility in spinal segments
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Perform manual muscle testing (MMT) of upper and lower extremities as necessary and compare differences bilaterallySwallow study and endoscopy for patients presenting with dysphagia. Assess oral cavity, pharynx, larynx, and esophagus.(12)Dysphagia occurs with solid foods and is improved with anterior flexion of the neck(21)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Patients may present with forward hunchback posture secondary to spinal stenosis(7)
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Thoracic mobility will most often be restricted.(3,6,7) Some patients may present with limited mobility in the shoulder, cervical, and lumbar ranges(11)
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assess integrity of peripheral nerves of C5, C6, C7, L4, and S1 and compare both sidesDetermine any limitations to reach arm overhead, hand behind back, hand behind head, etc. Barthel Index for ADLs assessment
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Check for differentiation of sharp/dull testing to note any changes in sensory distribution

contraindications precautions: Over areas of topical counterirritants recently applied
other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Radiographic imaging is the gold standard for diagnosing DISH.(11,16) Physical therapy evaluation and treatment may be indicated for increasing/maintaining spinal mobility and strength as well as treatment for related balance, function, and gait abnormalities. Physical therapy may also be indicated for decreased endurance due to lack of physical activity and for the treatment of pain associated with DISH
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Acromegaly(5) Ankylosing spondylitis(1,5,23) Degenerative disc disease(5) Discitis(9) Ochronosis(3) Osteitis condensansilii(3) Paget disease(5) Polymyalgia rheumatica(5) Psoriatic arthritis(1) Pyogenic spine infections(9) Reactive arthritis(1) Spinal epidural abscess(9) Spinal osteomyelitis(9) Spondylosis deformans(1)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Patients with neurogenic claudication, myelopathy, or dysphagia may require referral services to other specialties.(5) Refer to speech language pathologists for those with dysphagia/dysphonia(17)
treatment summary: Therapeutic interventions for DISH can include:  (18) –nutritional intervention to minimize saturated fat intake and carbohydrates –weight reduction and increased physical activity –joint protection techniques –corticosteroid injections and entheseal protection –minimizing falls and reducing risk of aspiration pneumonia –in extreme cases, surgical resection of cervical osteophytes . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Pain and tenderness Decrease pain and tendernessPhysical agents and mechanical modalities _ Thermotherapy hot packs can provide relief in patients with DISH(17) _ _ Manual massage therapy to decrease tenderness and muscle spasms in spinal musculature _ _ Walking and a generalized exercise program may help reduce pain(5)Discontinue use of modalities, splints, and braces as appropriateProvide strategies for home that address the patient’s pain Decreased spinal mobilityMaintain or improve spinal mobilityTherapeutic exercises _ Provide stretching and ROM exercises to focus on spinal mobility _ _ Exercises targeting the abdominal muscles (obliques, transverse abdominis, multifidi) to strengthen core stabilizers(9)Stretching, as indicated and tolerated, of tightened muscle groupsProvide strategies for home that address ROM/muscle tightness  Decreased functional mobility, balance, and/or safety with ambulationDecrease or reduce prevalence of metabolic syndrome and chronic heart diseaseExercise _ Provide a weight-loss program and aerobic training program to decrease the prevalence of metabolic syndrome and chronic heart disease(4)Progression of intensity as necessary to increase level of enduranceProvide home exercise program to continue with cardiovascular fitness .

maintenance or prevention: There are some preventive measures to follow to reduce the risk of DISH Maintain proper body weight and reduce risk of obesity Reduce risk of DM2 Improve cardiovascular fitness Proper nutrition to decrease risk of hyperlipidemia Exercise program to maintain or improve spinal mobility
patient education: More information on DISH can be found at the following: https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/diffuse-idiopathic-skeletal-hyperostosis/symptoms-causes/syc-20371661 https://www.medicinenet.com/diffuse_idiopathic_skeletal_hyperostosis/article.htm Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
